div.head: Question 2
De obedientia
div.p:
QVAESTIO. II.
De obedientia.

DEINDE quaeritur de secun
do principali, uidelicet de
obedientia. Circa quam quae
runtur tria. Primo de ipsa
obedientia in se, utrum sit uir
tus principalis distincta ab
alijs.

Secundo quaeritur de obedientia per com
parationem ad dominos etiam infideles: utrum
fideles teneantur sibi obedire.

Tertio quaeretur quantum ad Religiosos,
Vtrum religiosi professi teneantur in omnibus
suis praelatis obedire.

div.head: Articulus 1
An obedientiae sit uirtus
div.p:
ARTIC. I.
An obedientiae Sit uirtus. Con
clusio est affirmatiua.
D. Tho. 2 2. q. 104. ar. 2. Et 2. sent d. 44. ar. 4.

AD primum sic proceditur,
uidetur quod obedientia non
sit uirtus. quia omnis uirtus
est in medio duorum uitio
rum. Sed obedientia est in
extremo: quia potest quis
obedire ultra quam debet, &
non peccare: immo exinde poterit consequi
laudem

Praeterea dato, quod obedientia sit uirtus non
uidetur esse uirtus determinata & specialis, quia
hoc est obedientia: implere praeceptum. Sed sub
praecepto possunt cadere omnia opera uirtutum,
ergo &c.

Praeterea si obedientia est aliqua uirtus spe
cialis, erit aliqua de cardinalibus uel de annexis.
Sed nulla uirtus Cardinalis, nec aliqua de anne
xis nominatur hoc nomine, ergo &c.

Preterea obiectum obedientiae videtur esse debitum.
Sed nulla uirtus diminuit obiectum suum: Cum
igitur hoc sit obedire, tollere debitum, uel di
minuere debitum, ergo &c.

Praeterea obedientia est idem, quod imple
re mandata: sed mandata continentur in lege,
ergo idem est obedientia, quod iustitia legalis.
Sed haec est uirtus generalis, ergo &c.

IN CONTRARIVM est, quia obedientia
non solum dicitur uirtus, sed etiam mater uirtu
tum, & conseruatrix uirtutum, ergo &c.

RESOLVTIO.
Obedientia non solum est virtus, sed omnium mater,
& conseruatrix virtutum.

RESPONDEO dicendum, quod in hoc ordi
ne procedemus. Quia primo ostendemus, quod
obedientia est uirtus specialis: quia est pars iusti
tiae. Secundo declarabimus, quod obedientia ma
terialiter sumpta, non solum est omnis uirtus,
quia potest agere omnia opera uirtutum, sed etiam
est plus, quam omnis uirtus, quia potest agere ope
ra, quae secundum se non pertinent ad uirtutem.
Tertio ostendemus, quod licet obedientia ma
terialiter sit omnis uirtus: Formaliter tamen est quaedam
specialis uirtus distincta ab alijs.

Propter primum sciendum, quod obedientia est
inferioris ad superiorem, uel serui ad dominum.
Magis tamen large accipitur, ut est inferioris ad
superiorem, quia non omnis superioritas, pro
prie loquendo, dicitur dominatio. Nam praela
tus non debet existimare se potestate dominan
tem, sed uirtute, uel charitate, & seruiente feli
cem.

Cum ergo subditi multa debeant suis praela
tis, & serui multa debeant dominis suis. Nam sub
ditus debet honorem praelato. Iuxta illud Aug.
in regula sua: Honore coram uobis praelatus
sit uobis, & serui debent honorem dominis suis
Iuxta illud 1. ad Tim. 6. Quicunque sunt sub iu
go serui dominos suos omni honore dignos ar
guitur. Debent etiam tam subditi praelatis,
quam serui dominis fidelitatem, ut ex corde, non
secundum apparentiam tantum, & ut placeant homi
nibus, seruiant dominis suis. Tertio dicunt eo
rum implere mandata. Et si quis uellet ad hoc
intendere: posset forte multa talia multiplica
re. Sed quantum ad propositum spectat, cum
multa debeant subditi praelatis, & serui domi
nis: inter illa multa hoc uidetur esse potissimum,
quod debent eorum implere mandata, & in
hoc consistit ipsa obedientia.

Cum ergo haec sit iustitia, reddere alteri;
quod suum est, si subditi reddant praelatis, &
serui dominis, quae eis debent, dicuntur agere
actum iustitiae. Cum ergo multa debeant, & in
ter illa hoc sit potissimum obedire, & implere
mandata praelatorum, & dominorum, oportet,
quod obedientia, & impletio mandatorum sit
pars iustitiae, quia est quaedam redditio cuius
dam debiti.

Viso, quod obedientia est uirtus, & est spe
cialis uirtus, quia est pars iustitiae: Volumus o
stendere, quod materialiter loquendo est om
nis uirtus, & plusquam omnis uirtus. Sicut enim
dicemus de uirtutibus, sic dicimus de scien
tijs. Nam de una, & eadem re possunt determi
nare plures scientiae, sed non sub eadem ratio
ne formali, sicut de materia decernit Metaphy
sicus, & Physicus: Sed Physicus id est Philosophus
naturalis determinat de ea, ut est subiecta mo
tui, & transmutationi, quia subiectum in philo
sophia naturali est Corpus mobile: in eo, quod
mobile secundum se, & secundum suas partes.
Cum ergo materia sit pars corporis mobilis,
quia oportet imaginari materiam in re mota:
Ideo materia ut subiicitur motui, & transmuta
tioni, est de consideratione Philosophi natura
lis, siue Physici. Sed ut in materia reseruatur ra
tio entis est de consideratione Metaphysici, si cu
ius est considerare ens in eo, quod ens, ut patet
in quarto Metaphysicae. Et quod dictum est de
scientijs, quod una, & eadem res sub alia, & alia
ratione potest esse de consideratione plurium
scientiarum: multomagis ueritatem habet de
uirtutibus: quia materia moralis maiorem ua
riationem patitur, quam naturalis, quod unum,
& idem opus sub alia, & alia ratione sumptum
potest esse plurium uirtutum. Immo una, & ea
dem uirtus, sub alia tamen ratione, potest face
re opera omnium uirtutum, & potest illa eadem
facere, quae faciunt omnes uirtutes maiori, &
altiori modo, quod ipse uirtutes, ut patet per Philo
sophum in quarto Ethicorum. c. de magnani
mitate, ubi uult quod magnanimitas opera
tur magnum in omnibus uirtutibus, id est fa
cit omnia opera uirtutum, sicut honorabilia,
quia honor, qui est exhibitio reuerentiae omnibus uir
tutibus potest attribui. Vnde opera uirtutum
potest quis dupliciter facere, uel quia delectatur
in talibus operibus, & sic operantur opera uir
tutum ipsi uirtuosi. Vt fortis operatur opera
fortitudinis, & temperatus opera temperantiae
& sic de alijs: quia delectatur in talibus operi
bus. Nam, ut dicitur in secundo, signum ad ge
nerati habitus est delectationem, uel tristitiam
fieri in opere: Delectationem quidem quan
tum ad opera proposita: Tristitiam uero quan
tum ad opera opposita. Virtutes ergo operan
tur opera sua: quia delectantur in illis: Sed ma
gnanimus operatur huiusmodi opera sua, quia
vult inde habere honorem, uel vult inde esse
honore dignus. Ideo opera, quae faciunt omnes
uirtutes, facit magnanimus excellentiori
&c honorabiliori modo. quia vult inde esse
honore dignus. Ideo dicitur in dicto cap. de
magnanimitate, quod magnanimitas est orna
tus uirtutum.

Quod ergo dictum est de magnanimitate re
spectu omnium uirtutum, quia potest operari
omnia opera earum. sub alia tamen ratione ue
ritatem habet de obedientia, quod potest operari
opera omnium uirtutum, sub alia tamen ratione,
uidelicet quia uult implere mandatum superio
ris. Et quia omnia opera uirtutum possunt cade
re sub praecepto, uel sub mandato superioris:
Ideo omnia talia opera potest operari uirtus,
quae dicitur obedientia. Vt defensionem castri po
test operari miles dupliciter, uel quia delecta
tur in bello, & tunc agit opus fortitudinis, uel
agit illam defensionem, ut fortis. Vel quia gestit
inplere mandatum superioris hoc mandantis,
ut defendat castrum, & tunc agit opus obedien
tiae: uel agit illam defensionem ut obediens.
Sicut ergo dicimus de Religioso, qui ieiunat,
quod non placeat sibi ieiunare, sed quia hoc uo
uit, & uult implere uotum: ideo ieiunat. Vnus
ergo ieiunat, quia uouit: alius quia placet sibi
ieiunare: tertius uero ieiunat propter utrumque.
Ille, qui ieiunat solum, quia uouit: agit opus il
lius uirtutis, quae dicitur latria, id est diuina ser
uitus. sed ille, qui ieiunat, non quia uouit, sed
quia sibi placet: agit opus illius solius uirtutis,
quae dicitur temperantia, uel abstinentia, uel so
brietas. sed ille, qui ieiunat propter utrumque
agit opus utriusque uirtutis. Sic etiam est in de
fensione castri. Nam si miles defendat castrum
solum, quia placet sibi bellare: agit opus forti
tudinis. Si uero hoc facit, non quia placet sibi
bellare, sed quia uult implere mandatum supe
rioris: sic agit opus obedientiae. Sed si bellat
propter utrumque: agit opus utriusque uirtutis.

Et quia, ut dictum est superior potest praeci
pere opera omnium uirtutum: ideo uirtus obe
dientiae, materialiter loquendo, potest opera om
nium uirtutum facere, & etiam plusquam omnium
uirtutum, quia aliquando aliquid non est ma
lum, nisi quia prohibitum, & non est bonum, nisi
quia est iniunctum. Et etiam quia ad talia se ex
tendit obedientia: ideo potest dici quodammo
do de obedientia, quod potest agere opera om
nium uirtutum, & plusquam uirtutum. Dicunt ta
men quidam, quod iustitia legalis est uirtus ge
neralis, sed non obedientia. Sed hoc modo, quo
hic loquimur de generalitate uirtutis: obedien
tia est magis uirtus generalis, quam iustitia le
galis. Nam iustitia legalis est generalis uirtus,
quia lex potest praecipere omnia opera uirtutum.
Si ergo quis faciat opus fortitudinis, uel alterius
uirtutis, quia delectatur in illo, est fortis, uel est
ornatus alia uirtute. sed si hoc faciat, quia lex
hoc praecipit, & uult implere legem: est iustus.
legalis. Iustitia ergo legalis respicit mandata su
perioris, siue scripta, siue solo uerbo prolata,
siue quocunque modo insinuata, quia sufficit so
lum percipere uoluntatem Domini ad hoc, quod
teneamur, & debeamus eam implere, & ad hoc
quod agamus opus iustitiae, quod est unicuique
reddere, quod sibi debetur. Iuxta illud: Seruus
qui scit uoluntatem Domini, &c.

Habito quod obedientia est uirtus specialis,
quia est pars iustitiae: & declarato, quod mate
rialiter est omnis uirtus, uolumus tertio osten
dere, quod formaliter est specialis uirtus. Nam
sicut in scientiis dicitur materialiter pertinere
ad scientiam omne illud, de quo considerat scien
tia, sed formaliter dicitur pertinere ad scientiam
omne illud, de quo considerat scientia sub ratio
ne illa, per quam formaliter distinguitur ab aliis
scientiis: sic materialiter pertinet ad uirtutem om
ne illud, circa quod uersatur uirtus: sed forma
liter pertinet ad ipsam illud, circa quod uersa
tur sub ratione illa, per quam formaliter distin
guitur ab aliis uirtutibus. Magnanimitas ergo
materialiter est uirtus generalis, quia potest age
re opera omnium uirtutum, sed formaliter est
uirtus specialis, quia agit omnia illa opera sub
hac speciali ratione, per quam distinguitur ab om
nibus aliis uirtutibus, quia agit ea, ut inde sit di
gnus honore. Sic & obedientia materialiter est
uirtus generalis, quia potest agere opera om
nium uirtutum, & modo, quo dictum est, plusquam
omnium uirtutum. sed formaliter est uirtus spe
cialis, quia omnia illa agit sub hac speciali ra
tione, per quam distinguitur ab omnibus aliis
uirtutibus, uidelicet quia uult implere superio
ris mandatum.

RESP. AD ARG. Ad primum dicen
dum, quod quamuis uirtus sit in medio: tamen sem
per se tenet plus cum una parte, quam cum alia,
ut fortitudo se tenet cum audaci a plusquam cum
timiditate, & uirtuosus semper se debet facere
magis ad illud extremum, quod minus repugnat
uirtuti. Obedientia ergo non est in extremo
sed in medio, quia non loquendo de Deo: cui
in omnibus est obediendum, sed de aliis puris
hominibus dicimus: Etiam Praelatis non est obe
diendum eis in his, quae sunt contra Deum, &
contra ius naturale: tamen dato, quod non te
neatur subditus in eo, quod praecipitur sibi obe
dire Praelato: si potest illud facere bona con
scientia sine peccato: magis debet declinare ad
partem affirmatiuam, quod obediat, quam ad
negatiuam, quod non obediat. Immo si id, quod
praecipitur, potest fieri sine peccato: dato, quod
ualde uideatur difficile, uel quasi impossibile,
quod praecipiatur: debet subditus experiri, &
acceptare, si potest.

Ad secundum dicendum, quod argumentum
non plus arguit, nisi, quod obedientia est uirtus
generalis materialiter, sed non concludit, quod
sit generalis formaliter: nec etiam concludit,
quod obedientia possit facere omnia opera uir
tutum: faciet tamen ea sub speciali quodam mo
do, inquantum uult implere mandatum, per
quam specialem rationem est specialis uirtus,
& distincta ab aliis.

Ad tertium dicendum, quod obedientia re
ducitur ad uirtutem cardinalem, quae est iusti
tia, quia est pars iustitiae. Nam non est obe
dientia reddere. Domino quicquid debetur
ei: sed haec est iustitia, & obedientia est pars hu
iusmodi iustitiae, quia reddit domino aliquid quod
potissime debetur ei, scilicet implere manda
tum eius.

Ad quartum dicendum, quod obiectum o
bedientiae est mandatum superioris. Obediens
ergo non diminuit mandatum, sed implet, & per
ficit illud, & in hoc implet uoluntatem Domi
ni uolentis potius suum mandatum in facto es
se, quam in fieri. Certum est enim, quod fieri cu
iuslibet rei semper minuitur, donec res illa sit
in facto esse. Obedientia ergo respicit uolunta
tem domini, uolentis mandatum suum esse in
fieri, ut perducatur ad factum esse.

Ad quintum dicendum, quod ut patuit plus est
uirtus generalis obedientia, quam iustitia lega
lis, sed hoc est materialiter non formaliter. Nam
formaliter utraque est uirtus special, & sub spe
ciali ratione agit quaecunque agit. Nam iusti
tia legalis agit, ut impleat legem, uelut imple
at mandata in lege scripta. Sed obedientia agit,
quae agit, ut impleat mandata superioris, non so
lum scripta, sed quocunque modo praecepta.

div.head: Article 2
Whether the faithful are bound to obey unbelievers
div.p: ARTICLE II Whether the faithful are bound to obey unbelievers. The conclusion is affirmative.
D. Th 2. 2. q. 10. ar. 10 Et 2. sent. d. 44. ar. 5. D. Bon. d. 44. ar 3 q. 1. Ric. d. 44. q. 5. Dur d. 44. q. 3. To this material can be accommodated q. 104. ar. 1. & 6. in 2. 2.

SECOND, it is asked concerning obedience by comparison to masters even unbelievers, whether Christian believers are bound to fulfill the commands of masters even unbelievers. And it seems that not, because as it is said in John: If therefore the Son has freed you, you will be truly free. But all of us, as many as have been baptized in Christ, have put on Christ, and we are freed through Christ, and we are not bound to obey any lord, and especially an unbelieving lord.

Moreover Matthew 17 it is written that the sons are free from tribute. But through baptism we are all sons of the king of kings, that is, of God himself, because Christ gave to all of us the power to become sons of God, which power is most especially conferred on us in the regeneration of baptism, or in penitential contrition. Therefore such persons are free from tribute, and we are not bound to obey masters who demand anything from us.

Moreover servitude was introduced on account of sin, as was said above: But when through baptism and through penance we are cleansed from sin, therefore being cleansed we will no longer be servants, and we will not be bound to obey anyone.

Moreover, what absolves from a greater bond, much more absolves from a lesser. But the new law absolves us from the bond of the old law. Therefore much more it absolves us from the bond of any man, or of any lord, who is a mere man.

Moreover, what has been illicitly offered by us we can licitly resume if the ability is present. But many have acquired dominion through usurpation and through violence, therefore if the ability is present, they are not to be obeyed.
ON THE CONTRARY it is said in 1 Peter 2: Servants, be subject in all fear to your masters, not only to the good and modest, but also to the harsh.

Moreover in 1 Timothy 6 it is said: Whosoever are servants under the yoke, let them count their masters worthy of all honor. And the gloss expounds: even under the yoke of masters, even if unbelievers.
RESOLUTION A prince commanding unjustly is not to be obeyed, but one commanding justly and just things, whether faithful or unfaithful, is to be obeyed.

I RESPOND by saying that when it is asked whether servants ought to obey their masters, even unbelievers, in such a question mention is made of three things: of servitude, of dominion, and of faith. Therefore we will proceed in this order in this question, because first we will say some things about servitude itself, in how many ways it can exist, and how it was introduced. Second we will speak about dominion itself, how and in what manner masters are to be obeyed. Third we will treat of faith itself, whether it removes or diminishes the justice of masters, from all of which the truth of the question will be able to appear.

For the first point it must be known that servitude can be said to be twofold: natural and positive. For it is natural that those who are strong in intellect are deficient for the most part in physical strength: Because according to the Philosopher in On the Soul, we say that those soft in flesh are apt in mind, not that it is always so, but for the most part it happens thus, provided that softness does not come from phlegm, as in women, but from the rarity and goodness of complexion, and if those soft in flesh are apt in mind, nevertheless such persons for the most part are deficient in strength. Those hard in flesh are inept in mind, and for the most part abound in strength. On account of which it is well said: He whom nature has denied strength excels in counsel. And conversely it can be said that he excels in strength to whom the subtlety of intellect has been denied. Therefore according to this way the Philosopher in the first book of the Politics investigates who are naturally masters and who are naturally servants. For he who can foresee with the mind is by nature a ruler and master. But he who can do this with the body is by nature a servant, as is said in the same place. On account of which it is concluded in the same place that the same thing is expedient for master and servant. For it is expedient for the master that he be served, since he is deficient in strength, and it is expedient for the servant that he serve and be directed by another, since he is deficient in intellect. But to speak in this way about master and servant is nothing other than to speak about the natural aptitude for ruling and serving. But many are naturally apt for serving, not for ruling, who nevertheless are not servants but masters, and conversely. But here we speak about actuality, not about aptitude, and about those who are actually such, whether they are worthy or unworthy, and not about those who have the aptitude so that they are masters and are worthy of dominion.

We will say therefore that besides natural dominion or servitude there is positive dominion and servitude. And if it be asked how these were introduced, we will say that this question either asks about the fact and according to the name, or about the right and according to the truth. But about the fact and according to the name, these had their origin from the law of war. Whence Augustine in book 19 of the City of God says: The origin of the name of servants in the Latin language is believed to be derived from the fact that those who by the law of war could be killed were preserved by the victors, and they became servants, called from preserving. Thus therefore it must be said as regards the origin of the word and as regards those things which were done in fact. But it is not just that anyone should acquire dominion for himself through usurpation and through war without just cause for waging war. And if Christians wage war against Saracens, this is because they from the beginning were under us, and they hold certain things which were ours, and where our councils were celebrated. But if our question asks about servitude and dominion as they exist by right and according to truth, it can be said that they exist from just inheritance, or from just purchase, or from another just title, so that in this way some are justly servants, who have been justly acquired by some lord.

After we have determined about servitude in how many ways it can come to be, and how it was introduced, and how some ought justly to serve others, we wish to declare concerning dominion itself, how and in what things servants ought to obey their masters. Now it was said above that all dominion or all principate, insofar as it is a certain order, is from God: nevertheless the attainment of principate or its use can be evil, and in this way it will not be from God. Therefore to those who are justly masters and who justly use their dominion and their principate, servants ought to obey them as such in all things. Therefore if servants can justly withdraw themselves from the obedience of masters, either this is because they are not just masters, because they have acquired dominion through usurpation and violently, or this is because they use their principate and dominion unjustly. Since therefore we have treated two things: unjust principate and its unjust use, as to the first it must be known that sometimes from the beginning a principate is unjust, but in the process of time from unjust it becomes just. For Augustine in book 19 of the City of God says that when it was objected to the Romans that their Republic could not rule the provinces with justice, it was openly answered that they ruled justly and others served because it was useful for them to serve thus, because through the dominion of the Romans the license of wicked men to harm their subjects was taken away by the dominion of the Romans. But we do not believe this to be a sufficient cause of just domination, so that one can justly rule over the unwilling, however much he knows his dominion to be useful to them: nevertheless from this can be the origin of just domination, and in this way the unjust domination of the Romans could become just. For the provinces subjugated to the Romans, seeing that the dominion of the Romans was useful to them, and because from this each one enjoyed his goods, and no one was unjustly oppressed by another, each one delighted in the magnitude of peace, turning weapons of war into plowshares and sickles, and what was previously involuntary and unjust began to be voluntary and just. For if by the will of the subjects one can justly rule over such subjects, then also the peoples began voluntarily to use the laws of the Romans, and in this way they approved and justified their dominion.

Let us conclude therefore and say that to an unjust prince, that is, one ruling unjustly, a subject is not bound to obey, but if a principate which was previously unjust afterwards becomes just through the approval of the subjects, it will not be permitted for the subjects henceforth to withdraw without just and legitimate cause.

But we will add that a principate can be just from just attainment: thus it can be unjust from unjust use, which can happen in two ways. Either because he commands illicit things, which not only should one not obey, but also for not obeying them one ought to expose oneself to death, just as the martyrs did, scorning the commands of princes. Or this can also happen not only if they command illicit things which cannot be done without sin, but also if they command unaccustomed things, as if they wished to impose new tolls or new taxes. But this is more a juridical matter than theological.

Having passed through these things, we wish to solve the proposed question as regards those things which touch upon faith, because it seems inappropriate that the faithful should be subject to unbelievers. Therefore it must be known that the faith of Christ and his grace, or baptismal grace, do not free us except spiritually, because the baptized person dies just as the unbaptized. On account of which in Ezekiel 18 it is said: Why do you turn among yourselves into a proverb the parable: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, etc. As I live, says the Lord, all souls are mine. Therefore as regards souls and speaking spiritually, Christ frees us, but as regards bodies this liberation is deferred until the resurrection: then indeed the whole nature will be changed for the better, and all this principate will cease, and all this obedience about which we now speak. Therefore the faith of Christ does not remove obedience, nor does it free us from obedience or from justice, by which we are subject even to unbelievers, with Christ saying: Render what is Caesar's to Caesar. For the faith of Christ justifies us and makes us just and causes justice in us, according to that in Romans 3: But the justice of God is through the faith of Jesus Christ upon all and in all who believe in him. But what causes justice does not remove justice; therefore through faith we are not freed from the debt of justice. Rather we are more subject to such a debt, so that having the faith of Jesus Christ, concerning whom it is written that under heaven there is no other name under which we must be saved, we may be more debtors to all to whom we are justly obligated. Therefore faith, because it justifies us, therefore obliges us more to just debt, and especially speaking corporally, according to which way the faith of Christ does not free us.

RESPONSE TO THE ARGUMENTS. To the first it must be said that through Christ or through the faith of Christ we are sons of God spiritually, and we are freed spiritually. But it is not necessary that we be freed corporally from the yoke of our masters.

To the second it must be said that what is ordained for the utility of subjects does not remove their freedom. But before the conversion of the gentiles to Christ, the power even of the gentiles was for the utility of subjects: because otherwise the world could not live unless men ruled over men. Now therefore, because already a multitude of gentiles has entered the church, that person would be reprehensible who, being under the dominion of a believer, would procure by his own work to be under an unbeliever. But then it was necessary to be thus. It must be noted, however, that that authority from Matthew speaks about tribute: but Christ and his disciples, for whom all things were common and they had nothing proper, were freed from tribute.

To the third it must be said that the sin of the first parent not only causes a stain in our soul, but also causes penalties in the body. Therefore through baptism and through penance we are freed from the stain of the soul, not from the penalties of bodies. But principate, and especially of secular persons or laymen, was introduced on account of temporal goods. Therefore ecclesiastical principate is principally on account of spiritual good; by overflow or consequently it exists concerning corporeal things. But secular principate is conversely. Therefore baptism and the grace of Christ do not free us from secular dominion, much less from ecclesiastical.

To the fourth it must be said that one bond is not absolved through another except because one does not allow another with itself. And because when truth comes, shadow ceases, and truth does not allow shadow with itself, therefore when the new law came, the old law ceased as regards ceremonial things and as regards figurative things, because all things happened to them in figure. But the bond of spiritual servitude by which one is bound in baptism allows with itself the bond of corporeal servitude by which one is bound and bound fast to lay dominion.

To the fifth it must be said that from unjust dominion, while it remains unjust, one can withdraw himself. But if it becomes just, as is clear through what has been had, one cannot withdraw himself except by a reasonable cause intervening.

div.head: Article 3
Whether professed religious are bound to obey their prelates in all things
div.p: ARTICLE III. Whether professed religious are bound to obey their prelates in all things. The conclusion is affirmative.
D. Tho. 2. 2. q. 104. ar. 5. Et Quol. 10. ar. 10. Et 2. Sen. d. 44. art. 6. D. Bon d. 44. arti. 3. q ultima Ric. d. 44. q. ultima. Dur. d. 44 q. 4.

THIRD, it is asked: Whether professed religious are bound to obey their prelates in all things. And it seems that they are. Because it is said in Colossians 3: Children, obey your parents in all things. But one ought more to obey a spiritual father than a carnal one. Therefore etc.
Moreover blessed Benedict wishes that even if the prelate commands the impossible, the subject ought to try to fulfill it: therefore etc.

Moreover every religious order has substantially three vows annexed to it: to live in chastity, without property, and in obedience. But one vows chastity simply and poverty simply, because in no way is it permitted to him to have property: therefore he also vows obedience simply, that he ought to obey his prelate in all things.

Moreover an inferior ought not to have judgment concerning a superior, therefore it does not pertain to him to discern in what things he ought to obey, in what things not. It follows therefore that he ought to obey in all things.

Moreover every Christian is bound to obey his spiritual prelates in certain things. Therefore if professed religious were bound to obey their prelates only in certain things, that religious life would seem superfluous.

ON THE CONTRARY Augustine says in his rule: Let the prelate be in honor before you, but let him be prostrate in fear before God at your feet. Therefore if a prelate commands anything against God, he is not to be obeyed.

Moreover, as is had in Acts 4, Peter and John answered the Jews: Whether it is just in the sight of God to hear you rather than God, you judge. Therefore whatever man commands, God is more to be obeyed.

RESOLUTION. One commanding against divine law or against natural law is not to be obeyed. One commanding according to his state those things which are of positive law is not to be opposed. But in those things which pertain to the rule and to the custom pertaining to the religious order, by the law itself religious ought to obey their prelates; in other things not so, but counsel is given.

I RESPOND by saying that concerning obedience we can speak in three ways, either by comparison to the laws on which it is based, because obedience is a part of justice and arises from some law that one ought to obey another. On account of which one comparison of obedience can be to the laws on which it is based. But another comparison will be able to be to the rulers to whom it is owed. A third comparison of obedience will be to itself. Therefore according to all these three things we can respond to the proposed question.

For the first point it must be known that if obedience is compared to the laws on which it is based, we will distinguish a threefold law: divine, natural, and positive. But to divine law pertain most especially the precepts of the first table, namely: Not to adore idols, Not to swear falsely, And as a sign that we are subject to God, to sanctify the sabbath, that is, to give something of our time so that we may be free for divine devotion. But to these three things we are so obligated and ought to be so obedient that even God himself could not dispense in this nor absolve us from such a debt. For he could not dispense that the honor owed to God be given to another, and that with the adoration of latria some pure creature be adored. Nor could he dispense that man should swear falsely and take his name in vain. Nor could he absolve any creature from subjection to him, by reason of which subjection we ought to give something of our time to sanctifying the sabbath, that is, to being free for divine contemplation.

Having seen what must be thought about obedience insofar as it is based on divine law, because in such obedience not only can a religious prelate or any other prince not dispense, but even God himself cannot properly dispense therein, it must be seen what must be thought about it insofar as it is based on natural law. We will say therefore that to natural law pertain the precepts of the second table, in which God alone can dispense, but not any mere man as such. But to the precepts of the second table pertain: Not to kill, Not to steal, Not to commit adultery, the opposites of all of which God commanded. For he commanded Abraham to kill his innocent son, and the other, namely to steal by the sons of Israel, and to fornicate by Hosea. Since therefore it is asked whether professed religious ought to obey their prelates in all things, it must be said that if prelates command anything against divine law, in no way ought they to obey them, because not even God himself, properly speaking, could dispense in this. Also if they command what is against natural law, in no way ought they to obey them, because no mere man as such could dispense in this. For even the Pope himself is not to be obeyed if he commands anything against natural law. But if we speak of obedience insofar as it is compared to positive law, it must be seen how that positive law is established, because it pertains to the same person to establish some law and to remove it. Therefore if some law is merely positive, it will be the same person's to establish and to remove it. Therefore if a religious prelate wishes his command not to have force in some case, if he commands the contrary, his subjects are bound to obey him. Therefore an inferior prelate cannot act against that which has been enjoined and imposed by a superior. But a superior can act against things imposed by an inferior; but anyone can act against those things which he himself has imposed. Thus therefore we must speak about obedience as it is compared to the laws on which it is based.

But we wish to speak about it as it is compared to the rulers to whom it is owed. Therefore in this way we will say that to any ruler, according as he rules, man is bound to obey him, and not according as he does not rule. Thus to the leader of an army who rules over wars, man is bound to obey him in wars; to the father of a family who rules over the domestic affairs of the house, those over whom he rules ought to obey in such affairs. But to a religious and regular prelate, his subjects ought to obey in matters pertaining to the rule, also in those things which are customarily done in that religious order.

Third, we can speak about obedience by comparison to itself, saying that obedience can be taken in three ways: In one way as it is enjoined and under precept, and in another way as it is counseled, and in a third way as it is forbidden.

For obedience as it is enjoined and as it falls under precept extends to all matters pertaining to the rule and to all things which are customarily done in that religious order. For on account of this a year of probation is given in favor of those receiving and the one received. For this is done so that those receiving can test the one received, whether his conditions please them, and whether they see that he can make progress in that religious order. This is also done in favor of the one received, so that he himself may test and see concerning the rule and the constitutions and those things which are customarily done in that religious order, whether his conscience dictates to him that he can bear those burdens and make progress in that religious order. But this obedience is called sufficient by the great doctors, because it suffices for a religious person that he obey his prelate in matters pertaining to the rule and in the constitutions and in those good and honest things which are customarily done in that religious order. Second, obedience can be taken as it is counseled and as it falls under counsel, and thus it extends not only to matters pertaining to the rule and to the constitutions and to those things which are customarily done in that religious order, but also to all whatsoever lawful and honest things, even if they seem impossible. And this obedience is called perfect by the great doctors.

But the third obedience is called forbidden or is called indiscreet, when an inferior obeys a superior in unlawful things and in those things which cannot be done without sin, as if a prelate should command something against the rule or against God, because in such things in no way ought a subject to obey. Therefore from all these things the solution to the proposed question can be made clear.
Lateral Doubt: Whether man ought always to obey a higher prelate more than a lower one. The conclusion is affirmative.
Dur. d. 44 q. uitima. Raymundus in summa de obedientia. Et in Decretis c. 1. & 2. 58. d. Et. 2 2 q. 1. Non dicatis. Et Nimis iniqua de ea c. Prael. ibi Pan. 2. not.

FURTHER perhaps someone would doubt whether man is always bound to obey a higher prelate or a higher ruler. And it seems that he is, through that which is had in the text: If a speaker or curator should command something, is anything to be done if a proconsul commands the contrary? And if a proconsul commands, if the emperor commands something else, therefore one ought to obey the greater more than the lesser.

ON THE CONTRARY, because an archbishop is greater than a bishop, nevertheless in many things the bishop is obeyed and not the archbishop. Moreover a bishop is greater than an abbot, nevertheless monks in many things are bound more to the abbot than to the bishop.

Moreover spiritual power is greater than lay power, nevertheless if a layman commands that his rights and debts be paid to him, granted that a spiritual prelate should command the contrary, the subject ought to obey his lay lord.

RESOLUTION. Although a higher prelate or ruler is always to be obeyed more than a lower one if we speak absolutely, nevertheless from common law and from privilege, not always the higher but sometimes the lower is to be obeyed in something.

I RESPOND by saying that as it is in other beings, so it is in principates. For according to Dionysius in book 4 of the Divine Names, it is not possible in the universe to have two things of which one is not from another, or both are not from a third. Thus therefore also in principates it is not possible to have two principates of which one is not from another, or both are not from a third. Since therefore it is asked whether one ought always to obey a higher principate, it must be said that if there are two principates of which one is higher and the other lower, either this superiority is considered in certain things or simply. Because in certain things one is from another, but simply both are from a third: and then it is not necessary that the higher always be obeyed. For thus the order of the church is such that first is the supreme pontiff, under him are the greater patriarchs, under them are the primates or lesser patriarchs and archbishops, under them are bishops and abbots, and so on with the rest. Therefore we see this diversity of prelacies to have arisen from the ordinance of the church, to which ordinance it is believable that many convocations of councils concurred, because what touches all ought to be approved by all. Therefore in all such things there is something given as a fountain and origin of the others, as simply in the universe God, who is to be obeyed in all things. On account of which if man commands one thing and God another, God is to be obeyed in all things. And if the Pope commands one thing and an archbishop another, and a bishop or abbot another, the Pope is to be obeyed. But if those two principates, one with respect to the other does not have itself as fountain and origin, but according to the ordinance of the church there is there some superiority proceeding from its fountain, which superiority is not simple, and it is not at all necessary that such an inferior be entirely subject to the superior, and that in all things subjects obey the higher power, because in this case one principate is not simply from another or under another, but both are from a third or under a third.

RESPONSE TO THE ARGUMENTS OF THE LATERAL DOUBT. And from this proceed the three arguments made in this further doubt. For although a subject is more bound to obey the Pope than an archbishop and than a bishop, and a monk more to the Pope than to an abbot, and in these things exemption has no place, in other things however exemption can have place according as it is ordained by common law or by special privilege. And therefore subjects can be bound to their bishop in something more than to the archbishop, and monks to the abbot in some things more than to the bishop or archbishop. Nevertheless unless it proceeds from common law or from special privilege, a higher prelate is always to be obeyed more than a lower one. And from this the solution to the two arguments made to the contrary is clear.

But to the third which was objected about spiritual and secular or lay power, it must be said that those principates are not entirely of the same nature. And this is sufficiently solved from the Gospel, because what is Caesar's is to be rendered to Caesar, and what is God's to God. Therefore the principal question having been solved, and the further question according to itself and according to the arguments made to the contrary, it remains to solve the arguments of the principal question.

RESPONSE TO THE ARGUMENTS OF ARTICLE THREE. To the first it must be said that when it is said that parents are to be obeyed in all things, it is clear that it is not in all things absolutely and simply, but in all things which pertain to the rulership of the father. For if the father should command something against God, not only is he not to be obeyed, but he is also to be resisted. Thus also in the matter at hand, religious and other subjects ought to obey their prelates not in all things absolutely and simply, but in the way that has been stated.

To the second it must be said that blessed Benedict there speaks of perfect obedience and as it falls under counsel, according to which the prelate is to be obeyed in all things which can be done without sin. Nevertheless it is certain that a religious prelate can command some things possible to be done without sin from which a subject can licitly appeal, and to which the subject would not be bound by precept except perhaps by counsel and by perfect obedience. To the third it must be said that chastity has its special matter, and poverty also, but obedience has very general matter, because speaking absolutely one can also command illicit and undue things. On account of which a subject ought not and is not bound to obey in every way.

To the fourth it must be said that as regards those things which are commanded according to the rule or constitutions or according to the customs of the religious order, a subject does not have to discern. But if things notably more burdensome were commanded, such as that the bare ground should be his bed or something similar, he could licitly appeal if this were not customary in that religious order.

To the fifth it must be said that all Christians renouncing Satan and all his pomps and professing to live the Christian life are sufficiently bound and obligated, according to which they put on the new man who is created according to God. Nevertheless religious are more bound, because beyond these things they are obligated to the three vows essential to religious life, as those three vows are contained in their rule.
Literal Doubt 1.

CONCERNING the text, first it is asked about that word "After the aforesaid things." It seems that there is a perverted order there, because first he determined about the act of sinning, and now last he determines about the power of sinning, since power precedes act just as cause precedes effect. It must be said that there is a twofold order: of things and of teaching. The order of things is as regards being, and according to this order cause precedes effect. But according to the order of teaching it is not always thus, because with respect to us sometimes effects are better known than causes, and in the order of teaching they precede their causes. And because powers are known through acts, as is clear through the Philosopher in the second book of On the Soul, therefore the order which the Master held, he held as Master and as teacher, because it is the order of teaching.
Literal Doubt 2.

Further perhaps someone would doubt about that which is said in the text: "whether the power of sinning." It seems that he should not have spoken in the singular but in the plural, and said "whether the powers of sinning," since the acts of several powers can concur to sin. It must be said that although many powers can concur to sinning materially, nevertheless formally and principally the will alone is that by which one sins and acts well, as has been declared in many ways in what has gone before.
Literal Doubt 3.

Further perhaps someone would doubt about that which is said in the text, that evil will is not in us from God. On the contrary: For will and free choice signify one and the same thing and one and the same power. Since therefore free choice is in us from God, therefore etc. It must be said that will, as we said above, sometimes stands for power, sometimes stands for act, and as regards the way of speaking, for the most part it stands for act. For when someone says "this is my will," it is the same as if he said "I will this." And from this the solution to the question is clear, because the will to sin, as it signifies the power from which the act of sin proceeds, is from God. But the act of sin itself is not from God, or the will to sin itself, as it signifies the act of sin, is not from God.
Literal Doubt 4.

Further perhaps someone would doubt about the solution already given, because the very act of sinning is from God insofar as it is an act. It must be said that each can be said to be from God and not from God, both the power of sinning and the act. But the power of sinning is from God simply. But if it is said not to be from God, this is in a certain respect. But about the act conversely it must be said simply not from God; but if it is from God, this is in a certain respect. For what is in potency is not: therefore to be able to fail is not to fail. Therefore the power of sinning or of failing formally signifies some thing or some being: therefore it is simply from God. But if it is said not to be from God, this is in a certain respect. But a defective act or the act of sin formally signifies the defect itself; but if it signifies act, this is materially. Therefore it must be said simply not from God. But if it is said to be from God, this will be materially and in a certain respect and insofar as it is act.
Literal Doubt 5.
Further someone would doubt about that which is said in the text: "By the testimonies of many saints."
On the contrary, it seems that the Master's proof is worthless, because the authorities adduced by the Master do not speak about the power of sinning, but about the power of prelacy.

It must be said that any man is in some way a prelate over himself as long as he is on the way, in which existing he can act well and badly, because God made man and left him in the hand of his own counsel, and placed before him fire and water, so that he might stretch out his hand to whichever he wished. Indeed the prelacies which are over another take their origin from the prelacy which is over oneself, because he who does not know how to rule himself ought not to rule another. On account of which to proceed from the power of sinning to the power of prelacy and conversely are not undue proofs but due proofs if they are well understood.
Literal Doubt 6.
Further perhaps someone would doubt about that which is said in the text: "Through me kings reign and tyrants," etc. What is the difference between a king and a tyrant?

It must be said that for the present we can assign a threefold difference. One is that a king intends the public good, but a tyrant the private good. The second is that a king intends the good of others, that is, the good of those over whom he rules; but a tyrant intends his own good. The third is that a king rules over his subjects as sons, but a tyrant as servants.
Literal Doubt 7.

Further perhaps someone would doubt about that which is said in the text, that the Apostle speaks there, etc. But it seems from this that the Master does not solve the argument. For the power which the devil has is from God, therefore we ought not to resist his power. It must be said that the Master solves it, and well. For the Apostle speaks about the power of prelacy, to which as obedience falls under counsel we ought not to resist, but obey, unless he should command something against God. But the devil does not have any prelacy over us except usurped prelacy, insofar as we consent to him through sin. For through sin we become servants of the devil. And because we ought to repent of sin and withdraw ourselves from the servitude of sin as much as we can, therefore we ought to resist the power of the devil, because by withdrawing ourselves from sin we withdraw ourselves from the power of the devil. Therefore it is not similar concerning the power of the devil and concerning the power of prelacy, as the Master says in the text, and well. And at this point the present work on the second part of the second book of the Sentences is terminated. Praise therefore be to Christ himself, our unique Lord, who with the Father and the Holy Spirit is one God blessed forever and ever. Amen.
The end of the work which lay in darkness for nearly a hundred years after a single edition, which was about forty years after the invention of the art of printing. PRAISE BE TO GOD
